title: How to Use Tree Diagrams
text: When looking at a tree diagram, it consists of "branches", sometimes labeled with frequencies (whole numbers) or probabilities (fractions). Each branch of the tree represents a "choice" of sorts and each level represents the completion of a choice, and at the bottom of the tree--the leaf--houses the final outcomes. To get to the final outcome, you want to multiply all the probabilities going down the tree from the top to the end of the leaf.

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: We want to calculate P(R on the 1st draw AND B on 2nd draw). This means that the first draw needs to be R. What's the probability that the first draw is red?

title: Using the Tree Diagram
text: We want to calculate P(R on the 1st draw AND B on 2nd draw). This means that the second draw needs to be B. What's the probability that the second draw is blue?

title: Calculating Probability
text: Now, for the AND operator, we want to multiply together the two probabilities. Therefore, P(R on 1st draw AND B on 2nd $$draw)=P(R$$ on 1st draw)*P(B on 2nd draw). What's the answer?
